Introduction

Education in India during ancient times was culturally and spiritually rooted and encompassed a holistic learning. Gradual withering of political establishments combined with plunders and rule by savage raiders during the medieval times saw a fusion of education colliding with contradictory and supplementary wings added to it and left a deep scar on the national character of India as a whole, which concluded with yet another storm of colonization with the onset of the British Raj.

Education suffered its worst, survived with its spirit of wisdom and even attained its best by getting exposure to the world’s intellect, wisdom and modern science under socio-economic currents of its time. However, cumulative disruptions left independent India with a complex educational landscape.

Over the last seven decades, while great initiatives and incessant corrective measures and reforms have been attempted and a lot has been achieved, the fundamental purpose of education continues to face a learning crisis in schools. This has cascaded into low graduate employability, challenging the quality of higher education. The deeper problem remains — if learning is not adequately happening through education, what and from where are the youth learning?

The National Education Policy 2020 marks a decisive shift. It recognizes the strengths of India’s ancient and medieval educational traditions while addressing structural and pedagogical barriers that evolved over time. Drawing cumulative merits from previous policies and aligning with Sustainable Development Goal 4, NEP 2020 emphasizes holistic development, quality learning, and outcome-oriented education.

Beyond knowledge and skills, education must instill dispositions and values that help individuals become good human beings, responsible citizens, and productive contributors to the nation’s economy — either through self-employment or participation in the wider workforce.

As one of the premier think tanks dedicated to Fundamental and Applied Research on principles, practices, and policy in Indian education, we are committed to strengthening India’s learning-teaching ecosystem. Active participation from Universities, NCERT, NCTE, SCERTs, M.Ed and B.Ed colleges, and independent research institutions can enable sustainable transformation in learning and teaching.

To achieve this, the Pan-India Strategic Dialogue Series in Learning-Teaching Advancement will be initiated, open to all stakeholders. Each session will result in documented Insight Notes, which will collectively form an Annual Cohesive Synthesis Report to be submitted to the Government.

K V Atriya

Founder President

The Brigade Educational Trust

); }
